EXTRACTED VALUE: Despite the game's fluid control system and innovative lock-on features, its pacing and repetition simply mar the gameplay experience.
One of the most original and enjoyable racing games to come around in a long time.
The question, then, isn't whether or not you should play Soulcalibur IV, it's which version you should play.
Crash Bandicoot's latest adventure has too much backtracking and too many camera problems to make it recommendable.
Offers a decent challenge, but boring multiplayer a lack of variety drag it down a bit.
Hexic 2's new multiplayer mode adds frenetic new fun to an already-sharp puzzle game.
Save for its fish tank presentation, this is a wholly unremarkable version of Tetris.
Mutant Storm Empire is a quality entry in the increasingly overloaded dual joystick shooter genre.
The updated graphics and new modes in Bionic Commando Rearmed aren't quite enough to distract from the cumbersome controls.
The Golden Compass is just another family-friendly film cash-in with few redeeming qualities.
Blazing Angels has nice looks, but the action doesn't distinguish itself in any way.
While this online role-playing game may have been a hit for the PC and PlayStation 2, it feels very awkward and entirely out of place on the Xbox 360.
It's a short ride, but an amusing one while it lasts.
Scramble on the 360 is a faithful rendition of the original arcade game. If that alone doesn't get you excited, you should probably take a pass.
The few moments when Bullet Witch shines are impressive, but not nearly enough to elevate the rest of the game above the dismal plane of mediocrity.
A bit on the easy side. The platform-jumping sections aren't too tough, the puzzles not too complex, and the bosses fairly simple to beat.
It's incredibly easy to get engrossed in the rhythm of expansion and evolution, and you can happily lose hours and hours at a time.
This is a great, cheap way to get your hands on an underappreciated arcade classic.
Does not suffice in any facet of its execution and should be avoided by even the most fervent vehicular combat fans.
Sneak King isn't a good game, but it's so crazy and so cheap that it still manages to be weirdly compelling.
Fresh ideas can't save Bladestorm from mediocrity.
The XBLA version of Wits & Wagers is cheaper than the board game but not nearly as easy to recommend.
It's got a lot more depth and replay value than it might seem to have at first, and it's definitely worth taking a look at.
This Xbox 360 version of the game stays mostly faithful to the original, and it holds up well after all these years.
Hard Evidence offers few surprises and even fewer challenges throughout its five undemanding murder mysteries.
It's a little pricey for what you get, but this is still one of the craziest, most entertaining side-scrolling shooters you'll play.
NFL Tour would have made a great arcade game, but as a console game, it's simply too shallow to hold your interest for long.
Simply a smart game, bursting with great touches.
Rainbow Six is reinvented and reinvigorated for a new age thanks to beautiful visuals and top-notch tactical shooting action.
Despite a few nagging issues, NBA 2K8 is a fantastic basketball game packed to the brim with features and game modes.
Cast all fears aside: the latest Final Fantasy is the greatest game ever to bear the name.
The Egyptian palette swap and minuscule formula changes aren't enough to prevent Luxor 2 from feeling like the inferior Zuma rip-off that it is.
Lumines Live! has the same addictive gameplay as the PSP original does, but you don't get a lot for your money.
The gameplay hasn't changed dramatically, but better source material makes Lego Star Wars II a better game than its predecessor.
There's no reason to pick this one up, regardless of how bad you need a basketball fix--there are plenty of cheaper, better options available.
NASCAR 09 isn't a tremendous step forward for the series, but it's a solid effort.
Nearly two years after its buggy debut on the PC, Dark Messiah of Might and Magic comes to the Xbox 360 with even more problems.
Slick gameplay and gorgeous visuals are among Ace Combat 6's many strengths.
Big Bumpin' might have worked as a part of a large minigame collection, but on its own, it's sort of lame.
A big, loud, shallow action game that severely lacks in content.
With this game, you get what you pay for: passable gameplay and graphics but far too little bang for the buck.
BlackSite: Area 51 is an ordinary first-person shooter that's held back by a collection of bugs and other issues.
As archaic and clumsy as it can be, Earth Defense Force 2017 succeeds because of what a ridiculous bit of dumb fun it is.
If you're looking for a relaxed and somewhat mellow foray into the genre, Martian Gothic isn't half bad.
If you can endure some vexing technical flaws, Alone in the Dark can be a clever, satisfying adventure.
Many of the improvements are subtle, but the changes and additions to College Hoops 2K8 make it the best game in the series.
Saints Row 2 is crass, immature, and really fun.
Dull, repetitive, and carelessly programmed don't even begin to sum up how crummy this action game based on the Looney Tunes license is.
A simplistic, extremely short experience, with abundant flaws that outweigh its few redeeming features.
World War II shooters simply don't get worse than Battle for the Pacific.
The inability to call for backup in two-player hot pursuit games is completely unforgivable and keeps the gameplay score from being even higher.
To answer your two questions: Yes, this is a solid port of Virtua Fighter 5, and yes, the online play works just fine.
The game often shows its age, especially graphically, but never feels antique; what it lacks in visual style it makes up with charm.
A remarkable action game that tells a compelling story from start to finish.
Cloning Clyde delivers 35 levels of interesting, puzzle-based side-scrolling at a nice price.
Jewel Quest sticks a little too close to the Bejeweled formula for its own good, but it does require you to master a different set of strategies.
It might not offer enough new stuff to make it worthwhile for owners of FlatOut 2, but Ultimate Carnage is still a riotous racer in its own right.
Castle Crashers is a classic side-scrolling beat-'em-up infused with cartoon visuals and absurd humor, and the result is a highly amusing romp.
Fans of the genre can consider Land of the Babes a light snack between hearty meals.
Those who want a deeper, more satisfying platform adventure should probably save this for a weekend rental.
Skate's analog trick system is revolutionary for the genre, but the game surrounding those mechanics isn't quite as good.
With little notable improvement to the formula and steps backward in several key areas, SmackDown! vs. RAW 2008 is a big disappointment.
This horror-themed sequel's thrilling set pieces and bloody combat are remarkably satisfying but not for the faint of heart.
Golf: Tee It Up! offers respectable arcade gameplay and slick production values.
The only major flaw in Dave Mirra Freestyle BMX is that the game is a touch on the easy side.
The Club provides some old-school single-player thrills, but it fails to live up to its initial promise.
Surprisingly one of the most satisfying role-playing experiences to be found on the PlayStation.
Prince of Persia Classic is a fine example of how to modernize an older game while keeping its appeal intact.
Combining fantastic graphics and above-average gameplay, Dead or Alive is a fun and challenging fighting game well worth picking up.
Boasting nothing resembling extraordinary gameplay, it serves, rather, as a vehicle for the license.
It's the Master League that will have most veterans foaming at the mouth in anticipation.
And while the fruit of its efforts may not be the miracle this genre needs for a complete revival, it's just about as good as shooters get.
Blade lacks the energy of the film, the feel of the comic, and the standards set by other games in its genre.
Beijing 2008 proves beyond a doubt that rapidly pushing buttons is not fun.
Space Giraffe is an extremely weird and well-designed arcade game, but its unique brand of madness isn't for everyone.
In spite of its weak gameplay, The Simpsons Wrestling has plenty of laughs in store for devout fans of the series.
Easily the best iteration of the series thus far, thanks to improved AI, cleaner graphics, and tighter controls.
NBA 2K9's game is strong, but most of its new features won't be appreciated by the average Joe.
A beautiful, comprehensive, and highly enjoyable racing sim that's suitable for just about any driving enthusiast.
AI issues and the lack of any significant new features have NHL 2K9 skating backward this year.
Infinite Undiscovery feeds your need for narrative, but it's ultimately a shallow, flawed experience.
Excels in every way that counts, provides a lot of fun, and is well worth the price of admission.
Lost Odyssey doesn't rewrite the rules for turn-based role-playing games, but its great story and minor formula tweaks will keep you entertained.
For anyone looking for a "Puyo Puyo"-esque game with "Street Fighter" thrown in for good measure, this game will satisfy.
Call of Juarez takes few risks with its setting or genre, but it does what it does well enough to be enjoyable.
Rez HD is the most aesthetically pleasing and pocket-book-friendly version of this cult classic.
Pure doesn't blaze many new trails, but this off-road racer still delivers an intense, tricked-out thrill ride.
This is a game that will take most gamers months to complete 100 percent.
Fanged killing machines and clunky level design make this vampiric sneaker a real pain in the neck.
The brain-training experience comes to Microsoft's console, but it's unlikely to pass the test for most players' hard-earned dollars.
It's a great Mario Kart clone, and it succeeds where the likes of Mega Man, Bomberman, Diddy Kong, the Chocobo, and even Mario himself have failed.
Xenogears' reliance on story, subtlety, and mood make it Square's most anime-like RPG thus far, in many ways making the game one of its best.
Act Zero takes the Bomberman series to a new low with paper-thin gameplay, ugly visuals, and an overall lack of effort.
But even its title mocks the Army, literally one-upping its slogan while glamorizing a sector that, if anything, deserves scrutiny--not macho fantasy.
The squad premise of the game serves only to throw a few meaningless options into an otherwise thin game.
Some flashy action, a playful sense of humor, and a clean visual style bring this otherwise straightforward beat-'em-up to life.
This is an accurate emulation of the arcade version of Contra. Unfortunately, you're probably not looking for the arcade version of Contra.
Missile Command on Xbox Live Arcade only serves to illustrate that an analog stick can't replace a track ball.
GEON is a simple puzzle game that's more generic than its title would lead you to believe.
Omega Five may not be brimming with content, but what's there is visually dazzling and packed with challenging action.
Scene It?'s brand of movie trivia is one that will be enjoyed by both casual and hardcore movie fans.
A game that might be mediocre in its presentation but more than makes up for it in its gameplay and concept.
This entertaining update to the classic arcade game is fun while it lasts, which is under an hour.
Shivering Isles adds more than enough new and interesting content to give you a great reason to dive back into the world of Oblivion.
Getting pounded in the face with a real dodgeball might be more fun than this postmodern rendition of the schoolyard sport.
Eragon relies entirely on tedious, unenthusiastic gameplay that's way too shallow to sustain interest for more than a few minutes.
Capcom's superdeformed puzzle game benefits greatly from the inclusion of online play.
It's one of those games that will keep you coming back long after you've mastered it.
A refreshingly simple, addictive experience that combines appealing graphics and frantic gameplay.
The video game version of Order of the Phoenix captures none of the magic in the Harry Potter books or films.
Despite certain underdeveloped elements, this is the most ambitious and accessible Naruto game yet.
Just Cause is able to justify its relative brevity and disrespect for physical law with some extremely visceral and often satisfying action.
RES tries its best to be a fusion of two drastically different genres, and it unfortunately limits itself with difficult control and tedious gameplay.
The game is flawed on so many levels that only the most dedicated survival-horror fan might get some enjoyment out of it.
Despite the descriptive accuracy of its title, Word Puzzle is too shallow to satisfy fans of word puzzles.
It's all funny and little fun in this politics-themed party game.
As solid a game as any of its predecessors.
No amount of Xzibit influence or ride pimpage can save Pimp My Ride from its god-awful minigames and lousy driving mechanics.
Beneath numerous flaws there's a decent basketball game in March Madness 07, but you've got to dig too deep to find it.
Happy Tree Friends False Alarm is clunky, unimaginative, and more like a false start than a fun game.
The mobility of a box of trivia cards beats huddling around the TV nine times out of 10.
Konami's seventh Pro Evolution Soccer is a small improvement in terms of playability, but there's little else to make it worth the upgrade.
Acclaim Studios Cheltenham has produced a polished, high-quality racer that makes impressive use of the PS's aging hardware set.
There are a total of 22 missions, each with multiple goals, but most can be easily bested in one or two tries, save for the final mission.
By focusing almost exclusively on extremely intense one-on-one competitions, Table Tennis more than compensates for its lean set of options.
Graphically, "Chrono Cross" is nothing short of stunning.
If you ever cared about the arcade version of Paperboy, you'll get some nostalgic excitement from this emulation of the original.
Despite these shortcomings, it's still Mega Man, and the gameplay is still entertaining, making X6 an attractive package for hard-core Mega Man fans.
More sophisticated players will likely find this 3D platformer to be too repetitive and easy.
Its minigame format is a well-worn one, but the inclusion of online play in Fuzion Frenzy 2 gives the game an edge.
Iron Man's high-flying new adventure is hindered by erratic difficulty and repetitive level design.
Wing Commander Arena has the right idea, but the gameplay and presentation come together to form an extremely dull experience.
One of the most refreshing takes on the third-person action shooter to date.
Even if the new bells and whistles aren't enough to bring back established fans, this is still Lego Star Wars at its finest.
Between its unlimited continues and crusty looks, you're probably only going to be interested in this game if you liked it back in 1989.
Summer Athletics captures none of the passion and excitement of summer athletics.
At World's End's slick visuals don't make up for the dull, repetitive combat and uninspired mission structure.
While Hooters: Road Trip is quite bad graphically, its controls are even worse.
A basketball game that remains virtually unchanged from last year's version.
Streets of Rage 2 stands as one of the most well-crafted beat-'em-ups ever, and it still looks and sounds great and plays beautifully.
The pure joy of commanding a small army of malicious minions more than makes up for Overlord's minor shortcomings.
ProStreet is a solid racing game, but it's missing most of what made the previous games in the series interesting.
Commando 3 is an all-too-brief shooter that delivers high-caliber fun in solo and cooperative bursts.
KISS fans will be disappointed by the distinct lack of KISS, and pinball fans will be disappointed by the distinct lack of pinball.
This rendition of Open Season is a plodding adventure full of inane fetch quests and lifeless dialogue scenes.
If you already have the camera, you might as well download TotemBall. But don't expect to get much enjoyment out of it.
This multiplayer-only shooter does absolutely nothing with the Shadowrun name, and its unique strengths are offset by a lack of variety.
Although the graphical experience emphasizes clarity over extravagance, even the game's graphical palette exudes quality.
This clever physics-based puzzler is both challenging and addictive.
Sports Interactive's best title to date combines stability and variety in an immersive football experience.
Even with all the competition, fans of the original Contender will undoubtedly enjoy the sequel's familiar - yet vastly improved - look and feel.
This arcade game is relatively shallow and a pale imitation of its television inspiration.
Sure, there are a lot of levels, but most of them are very easy. The result is a great game you'll be done with in about two days.
Most of Tomb Raider II's improvements are cosmetic, and even those aren't really anything special.
Konami's seminal football game finally makes its way to the Xbox 360, but it doesn't fulfil many next-generation ambitions.
This Battlefield-style shooter isn't very original, but it's still pretty fun.
This game has a short offline fuse, but is a blast to play online or with friends.
Thanks to Viking: Battle for Asgard's mundane and tedious gameplay, the only battle you'll wage will be a losing one against boredom.
Visually astonishing from the moment you turn it on... A great fighting game with its share of flaws.
Instant fun for just about anyone that likes trivia.
Iffy controls and blotchy animations mean Smash Court Tennis 3 should restring its racket and try again next year.
Star Trek Legacy for the Xbox 360 captures the grandeur and feel of the epic starship battles in the famous television series.
Never before have technology, playability, and narrative combined as well as in Final Fantasy VII.
Unfortunately, after a few hours of play, it quickly becomes apparent that the only thing undone by the Grinch is your own personal satisfaction.
If you're a pinball fan, Fantastic Journey is a pretty amazing feat, and the price is definitely right.
Sea Life Safari's on-rails adventuring is about as exciting as scuba diving in your own bathtub.
Buried under the layers of poor visuals and rough control, there is indeed an engaging, playable game.
The average gamer is going to have a hard time looking past the game's generally poor production and repetitive gameplay.
The inclusion of different gameplay elements drag down what is otherwise an oftentimes surprisingly playable game.
It's a fairly sturdy, combat-heavy platformer with a good hook, but it lacks a real distinct attitude.
If you can get past the sluggish pacing and incessant overcomplication, MLB 2002 is a wonderful game.
The gameplay might not be anything special, but The Simpsons Game delivers more than enough laughs to make it worth a look.
NBA Live 2001 is not only the PlayStation's best basketball game, but it's also the best playing b-ball sim on any system.
Nothing really adds to the game's realism like the enemy AI, which is more advanced than any we've seen in console first-person shooters before.
Hardwood Spades is a Spades game for Spades fans, but even fans of the card game will probably be a little put off by the dull graphics and sound.
Easily as good as "Raystorm" or "G-Darius" and tough competition for "Einhander", Thunder Force V is a shooting fan's dream
Spectral Force 3 is a functional and predictable strategy RPG without a lick of personality.
A handful of quirks keep it from being great, but MLB 2K7 is an improvement over "MLB 2K6" in nearly every way, and it's a very solid baseball game.
The tennis is merely average, but the challenges and minigames in Sega Superstars Tennis are creatively done and a lot of fun.
Sloppy emulation and a sloppier enhanced mode make this version of Tempest a package to avoid.
A perfect example of awesome but unrealized potential.
While not absolutely groundbreaking, the gameplay is really quite fresh.
The best-looking and best-sounding PlayStation Formula One title to date, and it has excellent gameplay and features to boot.
The latest entry in EA's venerable hockey franchise is the best yet.
Blazing Angels 2 is a clear improvement over the previous game, though history buffs will probably hate the game's fictional missions.
LMA Manager 2007 is a welcoming introduction to the football management genre, with concessions for novice players and a handsome 3D match engine.
Interesting online modes salvage this derivative street racer from total mediocrity.
Even without player-created content, the Xbox 360 version of this online shooter holds its own, providing plenty of slick, thrilling sci-fi action.
A surprisingly competent port. Unfortunately, it's a port of a game that most fighting game fans consider to be completely obsolete.
Hanging 10 in this movie-licensed surfing game has its moments--just don't expect to enjoy it for very long.
Quite possibly the best 2D action side scroller ever.
Warriors Orochi 2 elevates hack-and-slash action to amazing levels of repetitive boredom.
This ambitious racing game delivers a rewarding off-road experience provided you make it past the initially steep learning curve.
Street Trace: NYC provides a few moments of multiplayer amusement, but it doesn't have enough going for it to be compelling for long.
To the game's credit are the tracks: They're well designed, and they get progressively harder as you reach higher levels.
Beyond the control issues, Alien Resurrection is gruelingly hard.
The original Galaga is an undisputed arcade classic, and this is a fairly faithful version of it.
The online works really well and it's a great version of a classic arcade fighting game.
It looks nicer, it plays faster, and with its lower barrier to entry, Armored Core 4 should appeal to more than just the series' faithful gearheads.
Even though the wingman mechanics and canyon races don't quite pan out, it's still a stylish and enjoyable street racer.
Dynasty Warriors: Gundam takes the worst elements of both franchises, and smashes them together into a dismally vapid action game.
While all the other pieces come together flawlessly, the lack of replay keeps the game from achieving greatness.
With a shallow single-player campaign and a broken online mode, Mr. Driller Online leaves little to recommend.
A tepid campaign mars this otherwise solid real-time strategy follow-up.
A little dumb and a lot dated, yet still marginally enjoyable if you're into retro shooters with lots of kabooms.
Like the mindless Hollywood blockbusters that it emulates, Turok features plenty of dinosaur-hunting action and not too much else.
Mad Tracks is the sort of idiot-simple game that you'll forget about five minutes after you play it.
It should go over well with fans of the genre--it's an altogether solid shooter, if a tad uninspired.
The single-player won't entertain for long, but the simple premise, clean visuals, and fiendish challenge deliver hours of multiplayer fun.
Lunar may not have modern aesthetics, but its gameplay and story are among the best of any RPG of any era.
If the heavy focus on trial and error doesn't rattle you, Stuntman: Ignition can be some explosive fun.
March Madness 08 has some new moves, but it's still not ready for the big dance.
Floaty physics and an underwhelming sense of speed add up to a decent, but not great, sci-fi racing game.
Even a merry band of adventurous thanes can't save this quest from ruin.
The quintessential Sonic experience is made even better thanks to the inclusion of achievements and a strong, competitive multiplayer component.
Elements of Destruction won't hold your interest for long, but it will satisfy your craving for blowing stuff up.
DDR Universe offers the standard sorts of changes and upgrades you'd expect from this nearly decade-old series.
FaceBreaker's impressive boxer-customization options are overshadowed by terrible gameplay.
The latest Armored Core makes up for the series' lack of progress by simply being fun to play.
Retro Evolved 2 takes adrenaline-soaked, addictive shooters to a level of unprecedented awesomeness.
For serious RPG fans who couldn't care less about the Final Fantasy brand of flash, though, it's hard to envision a more appropriate game.
Pirates and ninjas clash with other fantasy archetypes in dodgeball matches handicapped by a legion of drawbacks.
An over-priced arcade port with some neat ideas that don't translate into satisfying gameplay.
Disney's Meet the Robinsons is a fairly satisfying movie tie-in that borrows heavily from a number of classic adventure and action games.
Madden NFL 08 is a significant step forward for the series, bringing to the table features that are legitimately game-changing.
This frustrating collection of minigames is an insult to vacations, holidays, and every other blissful experience.
Getting to play chess or checkers online against friends is pretty much the sole reason to own this ramshackle collection of games.
Hour of Victory is practically broken and has no business being on shelves in its current state.
Call of Duty 3 plays every bit as good as its predecessor, and it has improved multiplayer and visuals, too.
Those exhausted with puzzle-genre conventions will find Exit to be a fun and inventive brainteaser with a wonderful sense of style.
This strategic RPG is ugly and frustrating--but it can also be a lot of fun.
Epic scale and depth of content make Two Worlds worthwhile.
Too much formula and too little imagination make Arkadian Warriors rigid and dull.
NHL 2K8 is a generally fun hockey game, though its new control scheme is a step backward for the series.
This short adventure game nails the feel of both the show and the island on which it's set, but struggles with some of the characters.
Def Jam: Icon plays well enough, but it really shines thanks to its crazy story mode and healthy roster.
In a word, this game is ugly.
Joust is a bona fide arcade classic, and this Xbox Live Arcade edition is a fine tribute to the 1982 original.
The game just doesn't capture the magic of the "Resident Evil" series.
It's arguably the most entertaining two-player sports game ever made.
This mech strategy RPG is rusty and dull.
You'd be better off with Electronic Arts' "NHL 2001."
One of those rare games that really draws you into the experience with fantastic gameplay and quality graphics and sound.
Rush 'n Attack can be fun for a few minutes, but the enjoyment quickly fades.
Basically the same as last year's model.
Full Auto is a neat idea, but unfortunately it's just one neat idea, stretched across the entire game. And that wears thin pretty quickly.
If you look past a painfully weak back story and the painfully simple graphics, you'll find there is an enjoyable game to be played in Ball Breakers.
Not even the allure of shiny robots with guns for arms can liven up this mind-numbingly simplistic and repetitive over-the-shoulder shooter.
There's a good game in Quake 4, but it's buried under several layers of highly disappointing graphical performance issues.
2K football returns with solid gameplay and a new focus on classic players, though the roster isn't the only aspect of the game that feels old.
This railroad-inspired board game offers subtle strategy and an easy learning curve for less than the price of a real train ticket.
It's somewhat disappointing when, only three to four hours into the game, you've reached the final climactic battle.
This real-time strategy game's convoluted controls make it hard to play, much less enjoy.
Kane & Lynch: Dead Men has a lot of promise, but nothing in this game works out nearly as well as you'd hope.
RoboBlitz is easily the most ambitious game released for the Xbox Live Arcade so far, and it's an impressive 3D platformer in its own right.
Dark Sector lacks the compelling storyline that it alludes to early on, but offers plenty of enjoyable combat nonetheless.
The newest entry in the revered series features plenty of awesome action, a great new character...and a bit of repetition.
The addictive gameplay and stylish design of N+ make the game as charming as it is challenging.
A solid game that's fun to watch, but it's no longer the only game in town.
EA Sports continues to experiment with its FIFA football series, creating a more challenging and slower-paced game for the 2008 outing.
Blue Dragon is an unexceptional RPG that does just enough to escape mediocrity.
It would make an excellent game for children who aren't yet old enough to tackle the meatier fare of "real" video games.
Battlestations: Midway strikes just the right balance between action and strategy to create a game that's as unique as it is enjoyable.
Poker Smash is an exciting and fast-paced puzzle game that puts an interesting twist on a fairly standard gameplay formula.
This new take on an old favorite adds new, exciting elements to the formula without getting rid of what made Pac-Man so good in the first place.
The latest Guitar Hero is an Aerosmith fan's dream come true, but the game's narrow focus and lack of content will prove unappealing to many others.
Sloppy controls and occasional glitches make Ratatouille one kid-unfriendly platformer.
This disappointing strategy game isn't nearly as engaging as the Discovery Channel show it's based on.
This classic fighter has aged well, but the XBLA version lacks both online play and features found in the Dreamcast game.
Gauntlet Legends wasn't a particularly good arcade game, and it's just as bad on the PlayStation.
It requires you to work too much to accomplish the objectives, and for too little reward.
Its madcap subject matter, good presentation, and friendly control scheme will appeal to many people.
Triggerheart is a passable arcade shooter, but doesn't offer enough to make it worth the asking price.
With new online modes and increased options for tuning and customizing your bike, MotoGP 07 certainly plays to the strengths of the series.
History Channel: Civil War is good for a few mindless hours of shooting action, but not much else. History buffs need not apply.
Tales of Vesperia is the best game yet in the series, and a beautiful and entertaining RPG in its own right.
Super Contra's blistering level of difficulty makes it best suited for those looking for an exceptionally punishing arcade run-and-gun experience.
Time has not diminished Ikaruga's sublime shooting experience. This game still trumps other shooters with its unparalleled design and challenge.
It's safe to go back into the water with Undertow, an under-the-sea XBLA shooter with solid multiplayer modes of play.
Top Spin 3 is a great tennis game, offering a deep challenge for diehard fans and one of the closest experiences to playing a grand slam.
Hardwood Hearts is a Hearts game for Hearts fans. If you don't already play Hearts, you aren't likely to get much out of this one.
Friendlier controls and a host of other improvements make Tiger Woods PGA Tour 09 great.
Pocketbike Racer is a bad kart-racing game that's often broken.
A decent port of an inherently disappointing game.
While DCB accurately duplicates the flow and gameplay of the tabletop game, its simplicity will turn off any but the youngest of players.
As a simple, yet effective translation of the German board game, Carcassonne proves an oddly addictive experience.
Complicated and unresponsive controls combined with uninteresting gameplay and a disjointed story keeps Prizefighter down for the count.
A novel idea, but in the end, it doesn't have enough variation to make it worthwhile. This one is only for the hard-core WCW fan.
A pretty fun game that's a little short on options but not bad on offering up some well-rounded soccer gameplay.
Bully's enhanced rerelease is raucously entertaining, but you may need to look past some frustrating glitches to get the most out of it.
The game would perhaps be visually palatable if not for the substandard frame rate, but alas, it's a little too jerky to really be pleasing.
As with Final Fantasy VII and VIII, the music arrangements are distinctly synthesized and sound 16-bit.
With its focus on weapon grabbing over weapon firing, Small Arms' shallow gameplay falls flat.
Wall-E is overflowing with charm, but the simple gameplay makes the experience fall flat.
Rayman Raving Rabbids is a fairly simple collection of minigames that manages to win you over largely on the merit of its personality.
This is a quality version of Defender that will definitely please fans of the original, but the game doesn't hold up especially well today.
MLB 2K8 is full of new ideas; unfortunately, it's also filled with technical problems.
Provides plenty of challenge for young and old alike.
An incredibly atmospheric and disturbingly gruesome deep-space adventure that will haunt your dreams and leave you begging for more.
Big strikeouts and even bigger homers make The BIGS a great arcade baseball game.
The Xbox Live Arcade release of Tron hobbles this absolute arcade classic with some technical problems.
Track & Field holds up fairly well and makes for some good, albeit short-term, fun.
Poor level design poisons Jericho's awesome but unrealized potential.
EA's latest NHL title creates one of the most legitimately exciting interpretations of the sport you've ever played.
The third time is the charm for Traveller's Tales--logical puzzles and great offline co-op play make this the best Lego game yet.
F.E.A.R. Files serves up two stand-alone expansions for F.E.A.R., though one is definitely stronger than the other.
Big, crisp graphics and online multiplayer markedly improve Puzzle Quest's oddly hypnotic blend of RPG and puzzle-game conventions.
Centipede and Millipede were arcade classics, but bad control and lame "evolved" modes make this package a stinker.
It's a mostly faithful emulation of the arcade original with a few interesting updates that should please fans of the series.
It's functional backgammon on your 360, and not much else. But if you're into the game, that's probably good enough.
Ninety-Nine Nights puts a lot of enemies onscreen but doesn't give you many interesting ways to dispose of them.
The poor AI and the limitations presented by the sole Ford license in particular keep it from being a truly entertaining game overall.
Like the original Legends, the sequel features an entertaining and overall lighthearted feel, but this time with slightly more serious overtones.
Costing less than a real deck of Uno cards, this well-rounded package is a successful translation of the classic card game.
What good is a set of tools that frustrates more than it aids creation?
One of the best 3D platformers to date, brimming with innovation, originality and fun.
A solid, complete baseball game, even if many of you have seen it before.
Who knew that samurai swordfighting could ever be so dull and annoying?
Symphony of the Night was an amazing adventure back in 1997, and even after 10 years, it's still most definitely worth playing.
UEFA Euro 2008 plays a better game of football than anything else on the market, but only just.
Electronic Arts improves upon the solid foundation they laid with Tiger Woods 06 and builds a great game in Tiger Woods PGA Tour 07.
While far from perfect, it is easily the best surfing game on the market, but more importantly, it's also a fun game.
Thanks to a crash bug and features that don't work well or don't work at all, Tiger Woods 08 on the Xbox 360 is a big disappointment.
NHL 07's thrilling new skill stick makes up for its bare-bones package.
Boogie Bunnies is a fun, albeit shallow little puzzle game.
It provides more of the same minigames fans have come to expect. The game's quick pace and great multiplayer modes make it an excellent party game.
Project Sylpheed is a short and needlessly complicated space shooter that gets by on its cutscenes more than its gameplay.
An ugly, boring game.
Card games don't get any more addictive than Lost Cities.
Thanks to significantly improved gameplay, NBA Live 08 is a good, solid basketball game.
Battlezone is a relic that should have stayed in the past.
This shooter is a painful exercise in pattern memorization plus frustrating trial-and-error gameplay.
You'll actually feel a loss if (and when) your star monster passes on. You might start to relate better to your monster than to actual people.
Alien Hominid HD is a charming and challenging arcade-style shooter that everyone should check out.
Grid is a classy arcade racing game, providing enough depth and variety to satisfy any fan of the genre.
There's simply not enough of a game here to prop up the pretty pictures.
This enjoyable turn-based strategy game has plenty to offer solo players and online skirmishers alike.
Rocketmen mixes cel-shaded graphics with serialized space adventure to provide a twist to old-school, top-down shooting.
Plotline aside, Colony Wars delivers the real experience with its spectacular cinematic graphics.
The artificial intelligence of TWINE's enemies is both shaken and stirred.
Aces of the Galaxy is an exciting, beautiful game that captures the spirit of classic arcade space shooters.
Are you dying to play some more Ms. Pac-Man? If so, then pick this up, but keep in mind that it's a very barebones emulation of the original game.
What do you get when you mix a 50-year-old animated franchise with 21st-century downloadable games? A poor microgame collection.
The game that once inspired awe with its wacky style and bizarre game mechanics in 1998 is getting a bit stale.
Rainbow Six Vegas 2 isn’t the best sequel ever made, but it’s still a great tactical shooter in its own right.
Heavy Weapon's arcade-style shooting is incredibly appealing, especially when you get into the ridiculous action in the multiplayer modes.
It's a new direction for the well-regarded series, but Circle of Doom isn't nearly as good as you may have hoped.
Derivative as it is, Conan is still a viscerally satisfying adventure.
In a word, MK: Special Forces is ugly.
Bejeweled 2 Deluxe brings the classic puzzle game to the Xbox 360 but doesn't make enough significant changes to make it stand out from the pack.
Koei's apologists will find Warriors Orochi to be an affable bit of fan service, but everyone else should just stay far away.
Great strategic gameplay is dwarfed by embarrassing technical issues.
As a graphical showpiece, DiRT is an unbridled success. It also happens to be an entirely enjoyable rally racer.
This alternate-history shooter is proof that an interesting premise can't compensate for boring and broken gameplay.
Yes, MX vs. ATV Untamed is more of the same. But at least it's a lot more.
The game is just far too buggy, easy, and uninspiring to hold your attention for more than a few hours, let alone a standard rental period.
The very small niche market of die-hard pinball fans this game is designed for should be extremely pleased with Big Race USA.
A worthy enough "sequel" to the original and can deliver an adequate number of thrills, though nothing unique or surprising.
Rock Band does a superb job of bringing out the wannabe rock star in all of us, and creates one of the best party-game experiences of all time.
With three amazing new games and two classics all in one package, it's impossible to go wrong with The Orange Box.
New multiplayer additions make this the best Lost Planet experience so far, but there's not enough here to warrant another purchase for veterans.
Roogoo's visuals are cute and the concept is simple, but this fast-paced game of quick reflexes is surprisingly fun and challenging.
No matter how big of a fan of the UFC you may be, the game's poor control and graphics just simply ruin the game and make it totally unenjoyable.
If you're frustrated by simulations, ESPN MLS GameNight is the game for you.
Even though it's not quite up to prevailing standards, Speedball 2100 still packs quite a bit of wallop.
Without the ability to compete against human opponents, this version of Cyberball 2072 is a completely useless waste.
Discs of Tron is a prettied-up port of an '80s arcade game that's barely even recommendable to die-hard Tron fans.
The ability to alter terrain isn't enough to save Fracture from becoming the latest run-of-the-mill shooter.
Technical problems mar what should have been a solid addition to the Xbox 360's growing library of strategy games.
While it can be fun at times, there are so many annoying gameplay issues that the overlying feeling of hindrance is difficult to shirk.
RayStorm is easily the best shooter currently available on the PlayStation (we're reserving judgment on "Xevious 3D" until we see the home version).
The combat in Hellboy gets repetitive before the first level ends and never presents a challenge. This is a boring, bland game.
Ninjas, ninjas, and more ninjas can't save the technically flawed, uninspired Tenchu Z.
This action-packed sequel isn't quite up to the standards of its precursors, but it's still a brutal blast.
You won't like it when this simplistic, repetitive, and occasionally broken game makes you angry.
As video games go, Sheep Raider is neither spectacular, nor challenging, nor interesting.
For a game whose main gameplay component is building up your characters, Digimon World 3 makes the process needlessly complicated and annoying.
In some ways the game has actually suffered--with its fluctuating frame rate and choppy animation--when compared to last year's game.
Eternal Sonata's superb art direction will dazzle you, but a dreamy story and exciting battles make it sing.
A game that successfully blends the action, survival-horror, and role-playing genres into a single outstanding product.
Beautiful Katamari includes few surprises, but it does offer up more of the enchanting gameplay and charming atmosphere the series is known for.
Origins won't win over staunchly anti-RPG players, but for fans of the genre, this is quite a deal.
Go Go Break Steady 's mixture of two gameplay styles sounds interesting, but it doesn't work out as well as you'd hope.
The spiritual predecessor to Halo is an interesting glimpse to the dawn of the shooter age, but the gameplay feels dated at this point.
A moving story, serene visuals, and brilliant puzzles make Braid an adventure that you absolutely should experience.
TiQal builds on rich puzzle traditions to create an exotic game full of ambiance and excitement.
Enchanted Arms is a capable and often enjoyable role-playing game, but it's also one that you'll likely forget as soon as you finish it.
Younger players will enjoy the variety and sandbox-style freedom of Bee Movie Game.
Thrillville: Off the Rails makes every part of building and running a theme park great fun.
A competent title with enough depth, playability, challenge, and originality to hold the interest of the discerning strategy fan.
Konami's seminal football game finally makes its way to the Xbox 360, but it doesn't fulfil many next-generation ambitions.
This 3D fighting game can be enjoyed by newcomers to the DBZ universe and Super Saiyan wannabes alike.
